id: unique id of the variable. NB: must be unique per sensor/platform/algorithm/output_name. Mustn't be changed
order: order of handling in algorithm. Not used everywhere. Can be modified.
measurementGroupId: This it to group variables by sensor/platform/algorithm and even source e.g. to distinguish jpl and daac.
measurementTypeId: This is to group variables which measure the same things, e.g. stc snow_fraction and spires snow_fraction.
output_name: variable name in Mosaics, PublicMosaics/geotiffs. May not be unique (v2024)
stc_output_name: Variable name in the stc cubes. Must remain empty for spires variables.
gap_name: Variable name in the gap cubes. Must remain empty for spires variables.
netCDF_varName: variable name in netCDF files. NB for spires is distinct from name and output_name. 20241206.
netCDF_long_name: long_name attribute in netCDF files
netCDF_description: comment variable attribute in netCDF files
calc_suffix_n_prefix: prefix or suffix of field calculated in runStatsForLinePlots()
label: Description (label) in Regions.writeStats()
type_in_STC: Data type in Stc files or spires files (for spires variables)
units_in_mosaics: Units indicated in Mosaics, except for albedos
units_in_map: Units indicated in stat files, in stc files for snow_cover_days, in mosaic files for albedo.
netCDF_units: Units attribute for netCDF files. Must be UDUNITS. ref: https://ncics.org/portfolio/other-resources/udunits2/. For variable standard names MUST be canonical units https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/current/build/cf-standard-name-table.html#:~:text=The%20canonical%20units%20associated%20with,used%20to%20search%20complex%20queries MUST be surrounded by "".
multiplicator_for_mosaics: Factor by which we multiply the value of the variable in the stc intermediary file to obtain the value inserted in Mosaic files.
divisor: Factor multiplied by min-max values to get the min-max values in Mosaics. Divisor applied on mosaic values to obtain PublicMosaic/geotiff value. Other divisors are extracted form Mosaics/or this file for runStatsLineFor, and hardcoded for STCSCAG_DRFS_snow.
nodata_value: No data value inserted in intermediary and mosaic files which type is integer (and not single/double).
nodata_value_web: No data value inserted in geotiff or other files sent to the snowToday frontend.
value_for_unreliable: Value for pixels below thresholds (handled within Mosaic) inserted in Mosaics or other intermediary files.
value_for_unreliable_web: Value for pixels below thresholds (handled within PublicMosaic) inserted in geotiff or other files sent to the snowToday frontend.
min: Minimal value of the variable (in Mosaics)
max: Maximal value of the variable (in Mosaics)
test_calc_albedos: 1: the variable is integrated in the unit test of Variables.calcAlbedos(). 0: the variable is not integrated.
test_calc_snow_cover_days: 1: the variable is integrated in the unit test of Variables.calcSnowCoverDays(). 0: the variable is not integrated.
test_write_mosaic: 1: the variable is integrated in the unit test of Mosaic.runWriteFiles(). 0: the variable is not integrated.
write_geotiffs: DEPRECATED. 1: a geotiff is generated for the variable in Step3 (regions.runWriteGeotiffs()). 0: no geotiff generated.
write_mosaics: 1: the variable is inserted in the daily mosaic data file in Step2 (mosaic.runWriteFiles()). 0: the variable is not inserted.
write_stats_csv: DEPRECATED. 1: the variable is integrated in statistic calculation. 0: the variable is not integrated. NB: if you edit this, don't forget to edit configuration_of_filepaths.csv and adding rows corresponding to variables
write_stc: 1: the variable is integrated in stc. 0: the variable is not integrated.
write_netCDF_v2022_0: 1: the variable is integrated in statistic calculation. 0: the variable is not integrated.
write_netCDF_v2023_1: 1: the variable is written to ESPnetCDF files 0:not written
mosaicSubsetSCAGDRFS: 1: the variable is inserted in the modscagdrfs raw file. 0: the variable is not inserted
modis_source_name: Name of the variable in the modis original file we import during Step0
modis_source: Indicates whether the variable originates from mod09ga .hdf file, modscag .dat file or moddrfs .dat file, all files being imported in Step0
mod09ga_bitPosition: If the variable is a bit-part of the modis composite variable, indicate the bit-position of the variable. E.g. cloud is a bit-part of state_1km_1, and bit-position is 0. If the variable is fully extracted from the modis variable, modis_bitPosition = 255 (no data).
mod09ga_bitCount: If the variable is a bit-part of the modis composite variable, indicate the number of bits that the variable occupies. If modis_bitPosition = 255, this field is not considered.
mod09ga_resamplingFactor: Indicates if the variable is in a lower resolution than the expected, by which factor we need to resample. E.g. if expected is 500m, and the variable is in 1000m, resamplingFactor = 2.
spires_name: Name of the variable returned by the spires.core.run_spires() method.
spires_output_name: Name of the variable in the spires output by Ned 2024. Must remain empty for stc variables.
spires_weightFactor00: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 0. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor01: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 1. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor02: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 2. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor03: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 3. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor04: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 4. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor05: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 5. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor06: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 6. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor07: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 7. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor08: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 8. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor09: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 9. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor10: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 10. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor11: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 11. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor12: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 12. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor13: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 13. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor14: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 14. For spires smoothing only.
spires_weightFactor15: Smoothing-weight if the variable = 15. For spires smoothing only.
web_ispresent: Here, dont put swe variables to value = 1 (web-app doesnt expect them).
web_layer_type: web_xx: attributes that are sent in the variables.json and in the root region .json for the website. NB: raster_layer: Only one raster not processed allowed in the web-app 2024-02-22
web_colormap_is_dynamic: 0: Web color map value range depends on values min max at the left. 1: color map value range depends on the range of values of the root region for the last available day. 2: color map value range depends on the number of days max of the ongoing water year.
comments: Comment on the variable

netCDF_long_name: STC-MODSCAG/MODDRFS clean snow albedo assuming flat surface
netCDF_description: Reflected fraction of broadband (0.28-4.00 micrometer) solar radiation, based on optical grain size from MODSCAG, no adjustment to account for slope and aspect of the terrain

netCDF_long_name: STC-MODSCAG/MODDRFS snow albedo assuming flat surface darkened by light-absorbing particles
netCDF_description: Reflected fraction of broadband (0.28-4.00 micrometer) solar radiation, based on optical grain size from MODSCAG accounting for darkening by light-absorbing impurities from MODDRFS deltavis, no adjustment to account for slope and aspect of the terrain

name: Clean Snow Albedo
netCDF_long_name: STC-MODSCAG/MODDRFS clean snow albedo on slope
netCDF_description: Reflected fraction of broadband (0.28-4.00 micrometer) solar radiation, based on optical grain size from MODSCAG, adjusted to account for slope and aspect of the terrain
label: Median Regional Snow Albedo

name: Snow Albedo
netCDF_long_name: STC-MODSCAG/MODDRFS snow albedo on slope darkened by light-absorbing particles
netCDF_description: Reflected fraction of broadband (0.28-4.00 micrometer) solar radiation, based on optical grain size from MODSCAG accounting for darkening by light-absorbing impurities from MODDRFS deltavis, adjusted to account for slope and aspect of the terrain
label: Median Regional Snow Albedo
web_helptext: Fresh, clean snow with a high albedo appears bright, while old or dirty snow tends to have a lower albedo and appears darker. The snow albedo measurement is a non-dimensional, unitless quantity that measures how well a surface reflects solar energy, ranging from 0 to 1. A value of 0 means the surface is a perfect absorber, where all incoming energy is absorbed, while a value of 1 means the surface is a perfect reflector, where all incoming energy is reflected and none is absorbed. This quantity can also be expressed as a percent with a range from 0 to 100, with zero percent absorbing all incoming energy and 100 percent reflecting all energy.

name: Decrease in visible Albedo from Dust and Soot
netCDF_long_name: STC-MODDRFS decrease in snow albedo from light absorbing particles
netCDF_description: Difference between observed visible broadband (0.350-0.876 micrometer) albedo and clean snow albedo estimated from MODDRFS grain size
web_longname: Decrease in visible Albedo from Dust and Soot

name: Snow Grain Size
netCDF_long_name: STC-MODSCAG grain size
netCDF_description: Optical snow grain size based on MODSCAG spectral mixture analysis. Espressed in micrometers.

netCDF_long_name: STC-MODDRFS grain size
netCDF_description: Optical snow grain size based on MODDRFS normalized difference grain size index. Espressed in micrometers.
comments: check min max and units

name: Snow Radiative Forcing
netCDF_long_name: STC-MODDRFS radiative forcing on snow
netCDF_description: Additional energy absorbed by the snowpack from light-absorbing impurities assuming a clear sky
label: Median Regional Snow Radiative Forcing
web_helptext: When snow impurities such as dust or soot fall on snow, its surface darkens and absorbs more solar energy. Snow radiative forcing is a measure of the additional absorption of solar radiation from light absorbing particles (LAP) such as dust or soot. Units of measure are Watts per square meter (W/m2) and values can range from 0 to 500 W/m2. This maximum value depends on incoming solar radiation (elevation, direct sun vs shaded) and the amount of dust or soot. A value of 0 means no additional radiation is being absorbed. A value of 500 means nearly all of the solar energy is absorbed (depends on latitude, elevation, clouds). Radiative forcing is calculated by the difference between the net (downward minus upward) radiative fluxes (irradiance) with and without LAP.

netCDF_long_name: STC-MOD09GA solar azimuth
netCDF_description: MOD09GA solar azimuth linearly interpolated to fill spatial gaps, used with terrain slope and aspect to estimate albedo_clean_muZ and albedo_observed_muZ
comments: check type and min max

netCDF_long_name: STC-MOD09GA solar zenith
netCDF_description: MOD09GA solar zenith linearly interpolated to fill spatial gaps, used with terrain slope and aspect to estimate albedo_clean_muZ and albedo_observed_muZ
comments: check type

name: Snow Cover Days
netCDF_long_name: STC-MODSCAG snow cover duration
netCDF_description: The number of days since the start of the water year with a value greater than the threshold for viewable snow cover fraction
label: Snow Cover Days
web_helptext: The number of days a region has been covered with snow as identified with snow cover percent greater than a snow cover percent threshold since a starting time. Our data uses 15% as the snow percent threshold and October 1 as the starting date for these maps.

name: Snow Cover Percent
netCDF_long_name: STC-MODSCAG on the ground snow fraction
netCDF_description: Viewable snow fraction corrected for canopy obstruction using forest height and vegetation fraction
label: Total Snow Cover Area
web_helptext: The areal extent of snow-covered ground, expressed as the mathematical percent of a region covered with snow. In the context of this website, the region refers to an Earth observing satellite's smallest measurement area. We use data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer at ~463m spatial resolution. Note that the Earth's surface is sometimes covered by clouds.

name: Viewable Snow Cover Percent
netCDF_long_name: STC-MODSCAG viewable snow fraction
netCDF_description: Snow fraction from surface reflectance visible from satellite

netCDF_long_name: STC viewable snow fraction status
netCDF_description: Flag value indicating the reason for ignoring or masking the satellite derived viewable snow fraction
label: Mask observed / interpolated
comments: not to indicate in mosaicSubsetSCAGDRFS, but we do insert in raw files

netCDF_long_name: STC days since last observation at this pixel
netCDF_description: The number of days covering the pixel/day which dont have observations. 0 if the day has observation, > 0 if day without observation. E.g. 10 if the day belongs to a series of 10 days without observation by the sensor.
label: Number of days without observation
comments: Not to indicate in write_mosaics, but we do insert after generating the Mosaic
check on min-max in mod09ga not implemented in code.
check on min-max in mod09ga not implemented in code.
in snowToday, reflectance min limit is -100 but in spires its 0

netCDF_long_name: SPIReS-MODIS Terra viewable snow fraction
netCDF_description: Snow fraction from surface reflectance visible from satellite. Expressed in percent for each pixel.
web_helptext: The areal extent of snow-covered ground, expressed as the mathematical percent of a region covered with snow. In the context of this website, the region refers to an Earth observing satellite's smallest measurement area. We use data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer at ~463m spatial resolution. Note that the Earth's surface is sometimes covered by clouds.

netCDF_long_name: SPIReS-MODIS Terra grain size
netCDF_description: Optical snow grain size based on SPIReS spectral mixture analysis. Expressed in micrometers for each pixel.

netCDF_long_name: SPIReS-MODIS Terra dust concentration
netCDF_description: Dust concentration based on Spires spectral mixture analysis. Expressed in 10-7 unitless (or tenths of ppm) for each pixel.

name: Snow Cover Percent
netCDF_long_name: SPIReS-MODIS Terra on the ground snow fraction
netCDF_description: Viewable snow fraction adjusted viewable using a Geometrical Optical model. Expressed in percent of pixel, for each pixel.
label: Total Snow Cover Area
web_helptext: The areal extent of snow-covered ground, expressed as the mathematical percent of a region covered with snow. In the context of this website, the region refers to an Earth observing satellite's smallest measurement area. We use data from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer at ~463m spatial resolution. Note that the Earth's surface is sometimes covered by clouds.

comments: Only one raster not processed allowed in the web-app 2024-02-22

netCDF_long_name: SPIReS-MODIS Terra snow cover duration
netCDF_description: The number of days since the start of the water year with a value greater than the threshold for viewable snow cover fraction, for each pixel. Water year N is set from 10/1/(N – 1) to 9/30/N for the northern hemisphere, and from 4/1/(N – 1) to 3/31/N for the southern hemisphere.
label: Snow Cover Days
web_helptext: The number of days a region has been covered with snow as identified with snow cover percent greater than a snow cover percent threshold since a starting time. Our data uses 15% as the snow percent threshold and October 1 as the starting date for these maps.

netCDF_long_name: SPIReS-MODIS Terra snow albedo assuming flat surface darkened by light-absorbing particles
netCDF_description: Spires reflected fraction of broadband (0.28-4.00 micrometer) solar radiation, based on optical grain size accounting for darkening by light-absorbing impurities, no adjustment to account for slope and aspect of the terrain. Expressed in percent for each pixel.
web_helptext: Fresh, clean snow with a high albedo appears bright, while old or dirty snow tends to have a lower albedo and appears darker. The snow albedo measurement is a non-dimensional, unitless quantity that measures how well a surface reflects solar energy, ranging from 0 to 1. A value of 0 means the surface is a perfect absorber, where all incoming energy is absorbed, while a value of 1 means the surface is a perfect reflector, where all incoming energy is reflected and none is absorbed. This quantity can also be expressed as a percent with a range from 0 to 100, with zero percent absorbing all incoming energy and 100 percent reflecting all energy.
comments: Min-Max web were set at 65-85 winter, 40-60 summer

name: Snow Radiative Forcing
netCDF_long_name: SPIReS-MODIS Terra radiative forcing on snow
netCDF_description: Additional energy absorbed by the snowpack from light-absorbing impurities assuming a clear sky. Expressed in Watt per square meter for each pixel.
label: Median Regional Snow Radiative Forcing
web_helptext: When snow impurities such as dust or soot fall on snow, its surface darkens and absorbs more solar energy. Snow radiative forcing is a measure of the additional absorption of solar radiation from light absorbing particles (LAP) such as dust or soot. Units of measure are Watts per square meter (W/m2) and values can range from 0 to 500 W/m2. This maximum value depends on incoming solar radiation (elevation, direct sun vs shaded) and the amount of dust or soot. A value of 0 means no additional radiation is being absorbed. A value of 500 means nearly all of the solar energy is absorbed (depends on latitude, elevation, clouds). Radiative forcing is calculated by the difference between the net (downward minus upward) radiative fluxes (irradiance) with and without LAP.
comments: Max web was set at 500 winter, 250 summer
Origin outside of snow-today backend

netCDF_description: Gap Snow fraction from surface reflectance visible from satellite

web_label_map_legend: Snow Albedo accounting for slope (%, for Snow >=10%)
web_helptext: Fresh, clean snow with a high albedo appears bright, while old or dirty snow tends to have a lower albedo and appears darker. The snow albedo measurement is a non-dimensional, unitless quantity that measures how well a surface reflects solar energy, ranging from 0 to 1. A value of 0 means the surface is a perfect absorber, where all incoming energy is absorbed, while a value of 1 means the surface is a perfect reflector, where all incoming energy is reflected and none is absorbed. This quantity can also be expressed as a percent with a range from 0 to 100, with zero percent absorbing all incoming energy and 100 percent reflecting all energy.
